Baseline privacy tier uses password manager with unique passwords per site
Baseline privacy tier uses TOTP authenticator app for MFA
Baseline privacy tier enables full disk encryption on all devices
Baseline privacy tier configures DoH via browser or OS
Strong privacy tier uses FIDO2 security key as primary with TOTP as backup
Strong privacy tier stores backup FIDO2 key offline
Strong privacy tier uses E2EE email provider with unique alias per service
snippet_ref: E2EE provider unique alias per service

claim_text: Strong privacy tier uses trusted audited no-log VPN always-on
High-risk privacy tier uses multiple FIDO2 keys with no SMS or TOTP fallback
High-risk privacy tier uses Qubes OS or equivalent compartmentalization
High-risk privacy tier uses Tor Browser for sensitive activities
High-risk privacy tier uses compartmented identities with multiple providers
30-day roadmap week 1 deploys password manager generates unique passwords for top 20 accounts and enables MFA on critical accounts
30-day roadmap week 2 enables FDE on all devices and configures automatic OS updates
30-day roadmap week 3 switches to encrypted DNS and installs privacy browser
30-day roadmap week 4 sets up email aliasing for new registrations and reviews recovery options
90-day roadmap month 2 acquires and registers FIDO2 security keys for critical accounts
90-day roadmap month 2 deploys VPN for daily use and migrates to E2EE email provider
90-day roadmap month 3 hardens device configurations and establishes secure tested backup procedures
Ongoing maintenance includes monthly review of password manager for weak credentials verify MFA enrollment and check updates
Ongoing maintenance includes quarterly backup restoration test and account inventory review
Ongoing maintenance includes annual threat model update if circumstances change
Password reuse failure mode results in single breach compromising all accounts using that password
SMS recovery bypass failure mode allows account takeover via SIM-swap despite strong primary authentication
VPN kill switch failure results in real IP and DNS queries leaking to ISP on disconnect
snippet_ref: kill switch failure leaks IP DNS

claim_text: DNS leak failure mode exposes browsing destinations to ISP despite VPN or DoH
Browser fingerprint uniqueness from extensions or settings enables tracking across sites without cookies
Tor with personal login failure mode links Tor session to real identity
Encrypted email metadata exposure failure shows communication patterns visible to provider and network
Cryptocurrency KYC linkage failure mode links real identity to wallet via exchange records
Recovery key loss failure mode results in permanent lockout from encrypted accounts and devices
Update neglect failure mode leaves known vulnerabilities exploitable
Alias service outage failure mode makes account recovery emails undeliverable causing potential lockout
ECH not deployed failure mode results in SNI leaking destination hostname despite encrypted DNS
Password reuse mitigation uses password manager with unique passwords per service
SMS recovery bypass mitigation disables SMS recovery and uses FIDO2 backup keys
VPN kill switch failure mitigation enables kill switch and verifies with leak tests
DNS leak mitigation uses DNS leak testing and configures OS-level DNS settings
Browser fingerprint uniqueness mitigation minimizes extensions and uses anti-fingerprinting browsers
Tor personal login mitigation never uses personal accounts over Tor and compartmentalizes identities
Encrypted email metadata exposure mitigation minimizes email for sensitive communication and prefers Signal
Recovery key loss mitigation establishes multiple recovery paths including backup key recovery codes and tested restore
Update neglect mitigation enables automatic updates with monthly manual verification
Alias service outage mitigation uses aliases on own domain where possible with backup access path
ECH not deployed mitigation monitors ECH deployment and uses Tor for SNI-sensitive browsing
AAL is Authentication Assurance Level from NIST SP 800-63B framework for authentication strength
AES-256 is Advanced Encryption Standard with 256-bit key widely used symmetric cipher
Anonymity is the state of being unidentifiable with unlinkability of identity to activity
Anonymity set is the group of users among whom an individual is indistinguishable
E2EE is End-to-End Encryption where only sender and recipient can read content
FDE is Full Disk Encryption encrypting entire storage volume
FIDO2 is Fast Identity Online 2 standard for phishing-resistant authentication
Metadata is data describing other data in communications who when where and how long
snippet_ref: metadata data describing who when where

claim_text: MFA is Multi-Factor Authentication using multiple factors
Privacy is control over personal information with data minimization
Sealed sender is Signal feature hiding sender identity from Signal servers
snippet_ref: sealed sender hides sender from servers

claim_text: SNI is Server Name Indication TLS extension revealing destination hostname
TOTP is Time-based One-Time Password from RFC 6238
TPM is Trusted Platform Module hardware chip for cryptographic key management
VPN is Virtual Private Network encrypted tunnel between device and VPN server
Zero-access encryption is architecture where service provider cannot decrypt user data
Website fingerprinting is traffic analysis attack identifying visited websites from encrypted traffic patterns
Report maintains strict non-operational boundaries with no step-by-step exploitation guidance no illicit URLs and dual-use topics framed for lawful defensive purposes
Report cites 67+ credible references including NIST standards IETF RFCs and academic research
Report provides three-tier threat framework mapping Baseline Strong and High-Risk to specific technology stacks
Report explicitly distinguishes privacy as data minimization from anonymity as identity unlinkability
Report states limitations and trade-offs for every technology layer
Report contains no absolute claims such as X makes you anonymous anywhere in document
30-day implementation plan achieves Baseline privacy tier with password manager MFA FDE and encrypted DNS
90-day implementation plan achieves Strong privacy tier with FIDO2 keys VPN E2EE email and hardened devices
Ongoing maintenance includes monthly quarterly and annual reviews of credentials backups and threat model
FDE verification confirms encryption status through OS security settings checking BitLocker FileVault or lsblk status
snippet_ref: verify via OS settings BitLocker FileVault

claim_text: Update verification confirms automatic updates are enabled and recently applied by checking last update date
Verified boot verification confirms Secure Boot is active by checking status in UEFI firmware settings
MFA verification tests enforcement by attempting login without second factor which should fail
snippet_ref: verify by attempt without factor fails

claim_text: Recovery verification tests annually whether you can recover access using only documented recovery path
Session verification reviews active sessions periodically for unrecognized devices
